column1: Sort/SDT TestProgam Standard - TP Naming and Directory Structure

column2: Standard Naming and paths enable automated test program and pattern transfer between FSM and ATM sites. This Standard covers TP Naming, TP folder Naming and TP Directory Naming.
USE this page FOR SDX/HOP/CMT Program Names for PROD NAMES ONLY - See the SDXProgramRename for ENG Program Names
Use ALL CAPS for all the characters of TP name
The Test Program Naming convention standard must be followed for all HVM Test Program releases including A-0 1st Si Readiness Test Programs i.e. AirSort TP and WTL
Test Program names are created using the Cake Tool only see https://wiki.ith.intel.com/x/9cMRYw

Changes to the below naming convention requires stakeholder notification, including the SMART dB[LYA FIFA] owner. SMART dB automation is in place to filter out non-standard Test Program Name from high volume diagnosis.
ALL test program names must rename sequential when sorted. Meaning when you choose field values choose them with this requirement in mind.
My Product is ready to release a program
Environment File has set TP_NAME = "SRFSDJXB0H22H002303"; this was setup by the base team when we start work on this Program/Release
I am releasing a program for 22H
This is the first time I am Releasing this Program
Build the program to the <product>\tptorrent\<CurrentProgram> folder
Rename the Program using Cake Rename script selecting the <MileStone>,<Sequential Release Number>,<YearWW>
My final Program name will be SRFSDJXB0H22H<current MileStone>0<CurrentYearWW>
I have been releasing programs and used up all of the available A-Z fields in Character 12
Increment Character 11 by 1
Restart Character 12 at A

column3: Need to ensure that the POP name is unique to each die type within a product family. This standard has changed (Q12024) as described in the WIKI Page for creating new product folders in Sort. Previously we matched the Atlas Product name but, as we move to a Many Sort Products to 1 Class Product (Atlas Name) we needed to change the folders/TP structure to represent <atlasName>_<UniquePopNameForSort>_<SDS|SDT|HOP|ETC> and the 3 characters here should match the UniquePopName for Sort (Field 2)
column5: SKL for Skylake, ICP for Icelake PCH

column1: Form Factor (Wafer Level vs Die Level, SDS vs SDT)
column3: Sort: WL (Wafer Level)
column5: WL for wafer Sort programs (excluding HOP)

column3: Sort Die Level (SDx): SD (Singulated Die);
column5: SD for singulated die (SDx) programs (SDS, SDT and SDM)

column3: Virtual Process: VP (Virtual Process Step after SDT)  (VPS no longer POR)
column5: HO for wafer Sort products on HDMx

column3: HDMx On: HO (associated with HDMx on Probe)
ENG: E - If you see E in char 3 you're looking at an Engineering TP. Refer to SDXProgramRenameTool for eng naming convention

Note: HDMx-on-Probe(HOP) name explicitly added ww13'21 for PVC and subsequent HOP products to provide a clearer naming for this platform. Previous HOP products (LKF, Elixr-springs) will remain using the old naming convention [i.e. Char3/4 as 'WL' and char9 as 'H' - LKFWLSCB4H15B012035]

column3: Note:
Prior to ww23'20 Joined/Merged Socket Char[5,6] was MC for Merged Conditions this was then changed to reflect
different flows where Joined and Merged are now called out specifically in Char5 and Multi-Temperature moving to 'X'
Fab Product Stepping/Revision Name
column5: Examples:

column3: 7th character: alphabetic representation of the stepping (A, B, C, etc)
column5: A TP supports B-0 and a new revision B-1 comes and the TP needs a change, 7/8 characters will rev from B0 to B1.
A TP supports B-1 and a new revision B-2 comes and the TP does not need a change. No TP release and the 7/8 characters remain as B1.

column3: 8th character: numerical representation of the revision (0, 1, 2, etc)

Sort: For test programs that support multiple revisions of a stepping, the lowest revision should be used. This enables NPI's with additional revisions for Fab process/recipe changes that do not require a change to the program to be released without a new Test Program. "X" should not be used for the 8th character in the TP name - it is allowable in the FOLDER name.
M: CMT
H: HDMT
V: V93K

Special care on these 3 fields is needed, these increment for the life of the product in sequential order. Even if we are moving from Tester or Socket to a new Tester or Socket these fields still increment.
column5: Example:

column3: If you are supporting multiple die such as left or right die or different product programs under a single product family, such as Clear Water Forrest (CWF) supporting a Clear Water Top (CWT) and Clear Water Base (CWB) or Sapphire Rapids supporting Left and Right Die EACH product should have a different 0-9 for Character 10.
column5: CWF has 2 Die/Programs,

column3: Choose this field pattern at the start of your product(s), multiple programs may choose character 10 for each to be unique, then increment sequentially characters 11,12 for planned releases.
column5: CWT (TOP Die) will pick Char 10 as "3" and start characters 11,12 with "0A" through "0Z" then expand to "1A" ? "1Z" if needed

column3: Char 10 TP family: (With in a product this should remain the same for the life of the "specific" product for this program family). Numbers only 0 through 9
column5: CWB (Base Die) will pick Char 10 as "4" and start characters 11,12 with "0A" through "0Z" then expand to "1A" ? "1Z" if needed

column3: Char 11: Rolling sequence 0,1,2.... used when rolling over Character 12 from A-Z. Numbers only 0 through 9
Char 12 TP revision:  Utilized A-H, J, K, M, N, P, R-Z and needs to start over at A after incrementing character 11
"I", "L", "O", "Q" are not to be used to allow error-prone letters that are easily confused. Lower case "L" looks like "I", etc.
Char #13 – Milestone Indicates current product Milestone achieved based on the following lookup table
column5: These are for internal use only.

column3: 0-PO, 1-ES1 , 2-ES2, 3-QS, 4-PRQ
column5: It's is not approved for external teams to use this field as trigger for downstream online/offline decisions.

column3: Use 0 also for Pre-Silicon TP Builds including WTL/Air Sort Test programs
Char #14 – Build - Incremented foreach TP Release within the same Release Date (Characters #15-#18 see below)
column5: Base builds for sort TP

column3: If the release has issues uncovered during the correlation run, the build character is incremented
column5: Z first Base build – TP base dev area

column3: 0 for first release candidate
column5: Release candidate TP builds

column3: 1-9 for every post-release build
column5: 0 first release candidate build – 1st correlation run
1 second release candidate build if correlation/kappa fails
2 third release candidate build

column3: Incremental TP Cycle - 26 Values a year A-Z
column5: A-Z for TP Cycle

column3: CMT & V93K TP Names end here at 16 characters using a letter in place of Incremental TP Cycle
Die Sort - Year, Work Week
Die Sort will utilize the Year and Work Week of the target release in the format of YYWW
Example: WW29 of 2019 = 1929
CMT Program names must be 16 characters do not use this for CMT Program Names

column1: ·         Thought process – work within the framework of current TP Naming standard
§  Use bit 10, 11, 12, 13 and 14 as defined in the table above to construct TP nick name.  In the example, bit 10, 11, 12 = 31J; bit 13, 14 = 00
o    For revision/patch TP, use bit 10, 11, 12 and append ‘r’ + patch/revision #
Example: Patch or revision 1 of 31J will be 31Jr1
·         Bit 10 is a TP rail number or swim lane.  Valid characters are 1-9
o    Each silicon flavor in a product family gets assigned to a rail

·         Bit 11 is silicon revision or TP sequence.  Gets uprev’ed for every major silicon change (litmus test – when TP for new silicon is not backward compatible to previous silicon).  Valid characters are 0-9
Bit 12 is TP series revision – do not use ‘i’, ‘l’, ‘o’, ‘q’
For pre si TP names use (A0 stepping) X0A, X0B, X0C, (B0 stepping) X1A, X1B, X1C...
Detailed Work Flow for Defining a Program Name
Abbreviations: FSM: Fab Sort Manufacturing (aka Wafer Sort); ATM: Assembly Test Manufacturing (aka Die Sort);  Factory: ATM + FSM; TP: Test Program; <POP>: POP Product

column2: Steps
column3: Key Points

column2: Get POP Names for your Product
column3: POP name is a 3 letter unique identifier for each product NPI.
column4: Infrastructure, test program and datasets must be unique

column3: See Here for more info

column2: Define TP Revision for this Product/Subproducts
column4: All Revisions should be sequential and are set from day 1 for all programs released until the end of life for that program/subprogram

column2: Gather TP Name Inputs and create TP name based on description below this table
column3: Ask Sort/SDT Product Owner for Product Family/Segment, Program Type, Stepping, Tester Platform, Revision, and Release Number
column4: Need these details to follow the convention

column2: Determine MDO and Factory sites
column3: Ask the product’s CE or VM for the names of the MDO and Factory sites where your product will run.
column4: Need disk space at all product has a CE and VM assigned

column3: Ask the CE for the names of the FSM Factory PE contacts
column4: FSM PE’s allocate disk at their sites

column3: Plan for sort, class, local labs and mega lab
Time: 1 day;  Result: Have all sites and contacts needed

column2: Create TP Name
column3: Create TP_NAME in the Environment file like TP_NAME = "SRFSDJXB0H22H002303"; this is used by the naming infrastructure as the SEED for the naming see Cake SDXPROGRAMRENAME Wiki Page
column4: Ensure the TP naming convention is followed.

column3: Setup TRC checks (Trace or other relevant tools or scripts in use) to validate the naming is followed
The first 3 characters in TP name, Product Folder name and TP dir name all match

column3: Ensure naming follows TP naming convention below
column4: Ensure the TP naming convention is followed. TPDB documentation is required for every TP release.
